Now, two years later, I finally picked it up, and honestly? it‚Äôs not bad at all. The game feels solid. gunplay is responsive and satisfying, perks and builds actually matter, and the heists (especially the newer ones) are fun and well-designed. It‚Äôs not perfect, but i‚Äôve been having a good time with it so far. But, and this is a big one, it‚Äôs still always-online, even if you‚Äôre playing solo. No real offline mode, no way to launch a heist without being connected. This has been one of the most requested features since launch, and Starbreeze keeps sidestepping it with vague answers or silence. if your internet goes out? you‚Äôre out.
Just want to play solo without worrying about servers? Too bad. It‚Äôs a shame, because the core game finally feels strong. But forcing players to always be online, especially for a game that‚Äôs so focused on solo and co-op PvE. Just feels unnecessary and restrictive.

Incredibly grindy game that forces players to do weekly raids with several alt characters, just to afford upgrading gear and keeping up with current content on single character. If you are not a god gamer with unlimited free time, you will never catch up to P2W whales.

Raids are unforgiving with several different bosses. A single boss fight can take up to 20+ minutes to finish, but a mistake from player can wipe the whole raid even at the very end and reset the boss. 

This can mean that even in weekly farm content it takes hours to kill a single boss. Random parties can be heavily impacted by gatekeeping, because no one wants to waste hours on old content.

There is absolutely no variation to weekly grind, you have to repeat same weekly dungeons and raids until new ones arrive.
Developer Smilegate RPG keeps introducing new item types for players to sink/sacrifice more time into upgrading, which also includes a lot of RNG.

completion: For $80 this might not make sense, however, when you can pick it up for a few dollars at a Steam Sale this game offers a fantastic multiplayer experience. It is not so fluid and the gunplay not so clicky to become something akin to COD given that the game still has weight to it. I think the game is over hated and I have had a lot of fun with it. At the same time the lack of a campaign and unintuitive way of unlocking guns can be a bit frustrating. At the moment though this is my favourite FPS multiplayer experience.

Absolutely incredible game, I first played it in 2022 on Twitch and I liked it then but i had to rush to finish the story (took me 49 hours). Now, in 2025, a couple years after 2.0 came out, the game is even better. I liked it back then, but now it feels like one of the best games of all time, easily on par with Witcher 3. It needed some time in the oven and now it's near perfect. 

I do recommend getting some mods for the character customization, that is this game's primary con for me, there just isn't enough customization options and some of them weirdly lock you to gendered things. Thankfully, there are mods to fix it, but I would still say the vanilla game is near perfect, and the modding scene is well supported by CDPR so it's pretty easy to install everything, even right in the middle of a playthrough. Speaking of playthroughs, im at 200+ hours on my second playthrough now, not including the first 50, and I think i'll finish the game around 300 hours total with everything done and seen (for the most part). I'll still have to do a third playthrough for the last lifepath :3 All this to say, this game is enormous and I love playing in this world

With 700+ hours played over five years ‚Äî since launch on GOG ‚Äî I can confidently say I‚Äôve seen Cyberpunk 2077 at its worst and at its absolute best.
From a rough, buggy release, it rose like a phoenix into a visually breathtaking, deeply immersive masterpiece.
The story is mature, emotional, and gripping, with exceptionally well-written characters.
Playing as female V completely won me over ‚Äî Cherami Leigh‚Äôs brilliant voice acting adds real depth and humanity.
Johnny Silverhand (portrayed by Keanu Reeves) is charismatic, abrasive, and surprisingly layered.
And Judy‚Ä¶ beautifully written, emotionally grounded, and unforgettable.
These characters don‚Äôt just exist in the story; they stay with you.
Combat and progression are flexible and rewarding, even for someone who isn‚Äôt really into FPS games.
High replayability, meaningful choices, and multiple endings make every playthrough worthwhile.
Thanks to modders, the game has become even richer and more customizable.
I‚Äôve tried and used many mods long-term ‚Äî not as gimmicks, but because they genuinely improved the experience.
Over the years, Cyberpunk 2077 didn‚Äôt just recover ‚Äî it evolved into something truly remarkable.

Review:
completion:
Any maps with timing-based obstacles is just a crapshoot. With every heist being hosted on their servers rather than one of you in the lobby, the latency is incredibly bad. I have great internet here, I can play League, Overwatch 2, no problems whatsoever. Payday 3's servers on the other hand are so bad that you can be seen by a camera, back around a corner and still have the detection counter counting up for another second. 

Then the lasers in vents, like on First World Bank for example, or the lasers to the back area in First World Bank, they will look deactivated on your screen, but because of the latency they probably aren't. Their solo beta is a start to getting back to a more stable game like Payday 2, but a locally-hosted multiplayer, like Payday 2, will be so nice to get.

It's still an alright game, but it would be so much better to have crisp responses since everything is close timings in stealth.

My only real gripe with the game is honing is the progression system and boy is it aggrivating, if you don't wanna spend money you gotta grind for a few days to attempt to hone an item. Oh it's like a 2% chance to upgrade? well pony up some cash or keep grinding. It sucks that f2p is so held back but I understand it's the play model they're choosing. 

Overall it's a 5/10 great boss fights and fun mechs but the end game progression sucks. Perhaps it's changed but with POE2 out I don't see a reason to go back.

Review:
completion:
I have not had this much fun exploring in a game in a long time. And the fact that it's just a tad easier than other Souls games in terms of enemies and the generousity of checkpoints (bonfires, site of grace etc) just makes a bit less frustrating when dying. I feel like this game can be played many times over without getting bored. 
It is however giving me seconds-long lag spikes every now and then, which I dont know where it comes from, whether it's poorly optimization for PC or something running in the background that sets it off. And the game keeps running while the spike happens (not like freeze/lag if GPU was throttling or something, seems more like packet loss spike) so it kind of catches up after a sec or two, so I dont think it's hardware related (1440p, 5700x3d, 32GB ram, rtx 3080). It's getting annoying and i've seen that this is a known issue, I just assumed they would have fixed it after 3-4 years.
But other than that, really awesome game.

Review:
completion:
What I love about Cyberpunk 2077 is the story and the way the world pulls you in. Night City feels alive in a way that is hard to explain. You are not just following a main quest. You are listening to conversations. Reading messages. Stumbling into side stories that feel personal and sometimes uncomfortable. The game rewards slowing down and paying attention more than rushing from objective to objective.

I also love how open it all feels. You can get lost in the city without feeling like you are playing it wrong. Some nights you follow the story. Other times you just drive, explore, or take on a small job that turns into something bigger. The game is at its best when you let go of the need to complete everything and just exist in the world for a while.

Review:
completion:
I started playing BF games with BF1942, at launch. I know that on Steam, it becomes cool to hate on games that are hated on by others - whether to get rewards or whatever from others. Having seen the reviews for BF2042, I had very low expectations.

But, at $3, and with a Road to BF6 event for free, what was there to loose?

Simply put, I had a lot of fun. I finished the BF6 event, and enjoyed my journey there. After years of patches, and content updates, and changes - the final state of BF2042 is actually a lot of fun. Honestly I enjoyed it more than BF1 or BFV - neither of which did I personally find enjoyable, especially BFV, which has nothing do with WWII.

I especially like the option to just play against AI if you so choose. Sometimes you just want to sit back and relax, and playing against the AI is a great way to do that, especially with others.

On sale, I think there is tremendous value to this game. I enjoyed it and would recommend it. And thats from a BF player who has been here since day 1 that there was a BF.
